simplified: Your dreams can show you thoughts and feelings you did not know you had. Many people dream about flying, falling, losing their teeth, or being naked in public. These dreams often mean similar things for most people. But to understand what they mean for you, connect them to the events and feelings in your daily life.

One of the most interesting examples of wild animals in a city is the wild dogs of Moscow. In Moscow, about 35,000 dogs live on the streets. Some dogs were born wild, and others were once pets but were left by their owners. Some dogs live alone, and some live in packs. In 2010, scientists studied these dogs and found that they have adapted well to city life. They know it is safer to cross the street with people, and some dogs seem to understand traffic lights.

Wonder is the first novel by RJ Palacio. She is from New York. On her website, she says the idea came after she saw a girl on the street whose face looked different. Wonder is a bestseller in the United States. It has won several awards. Many schools use the book to start talks about bullying, friendship, and being different. People are making a film of the book. Many people, like me, want to see what RJ Palacio writes next.

Chloe has two pet rats, Zena and Roxy. She knows they are not typical pets. She often explains that rats are not dirty and can be great pets if you look after them well. She understands why people react badly. She did not like rats before, but then her friend Martin showed her his rats. She saw they were affectionate and intelligent. Last year, one of Martin's rats had babies, so Chloe decided to have two of them.

Cape Town can be dangerous for baboons. Cars hit some baboons, and some die in crashes. Some baboons touch power cables and get a bad electric shock. Baboons are in danger. The city council has a team called Baboon Monitors. The team helps baboons and tries to stop problems with people. The monitors chase baboons out of the city. They also catch baboons and take them to the countryside. This plan works a bit, but it is hard to stop baboons from coming back. They see the city as an easy place to find food.

I work for a global IT company. Their head office is in the United States, so I do all my work online from home. I do not waste time traveling or talking too much with colleagues. I work on different projects, and this flexible schedule is helpful. If my children have a school event or I have a dentist appointment, I can take time off. The problem is that I do not have set work hours, so I often work late into the evening. Sometimes I even skip dinner to finish my work.

In the 1990s, graffiti stayed popular. Street art also grew fast around the world. Some artists wanted to talk about politics. They made art to make people think about war, unfairness, and unfair treatment. Other artists wanted to create beautiful work. In South America, many street artists worked in poor areas. They painted grey city walls and added color, life, and beauty.

Social media, magazines, and shop windows show people many things to buy every day. British people are buying more clothes and shoes than ever before. Online shopping makes it easy to buy without thinking. Big brands sell very cheap clothes. Many people wear these clothes two or three times and then throw them away.

Sam looked at the sun. He saw dust far away. A car made the dust as it drove to the Big House. The horses kicked at flies and moved their tails. They did not care that their owner came for the first time in ten months. Sam waited. Mr Carter did not come here often. He only came if he must. Sam liked this. Sam wanted to keep his job, so he stayed away from his boss. Mr Carter wiped sweat from his neck. His shirt was wet. The wet parts looked like shapes on a map. His skin was red from the June sun. He usually stayed inside. He made money, and other people did the work for him.

Many people in Berlin, Germany said shooting pigs is cruel. Hunters and animal lovers had big arguments. After protests, the city council chose a peaceful plan. They will not shoot pigs. They put up fences. They passed a rule: people must not feed pigs. We do not know if this plan will work. Warmer winters help more pigs live, so there are more pigs than before.

Suzanne Collins loves old Greek myths. This love gave her ideas for The Hunger Games. When she was a child, her favorite story was Theseus and the Minotaur. In that story, Crete rules the city of Athens. The people of Athens fight back. As a punishment, King Minos makes them send seven boys and seven girls to Crete every year. The young people are thrown into a maze. A monster called the Minotaur lives there and eats them. But one young man, Theseus, fights the Minotaur and kills it. Suzanne sees Katniss Everdeen as a future Theseus.

Zoos bring people and animals together. They teach people about conservation and encourage them to protect animals and their homes. Some zoos give safe homes to animals that were hurt in circuses or left behind by owners. Zoos also study animal behavior and learn how to treat illnesses.

There is a new idea that says we should not buy too many things. It is called 'Buy Nothing.' It started in Canada in the early 1990s. Later it came to the United States. In the U.S., people use it to say no to Black Friday and Cyber Monday on Thanksgiving weekend. These are big shopping days. Many people spend too much money then and buy too many things. On Buy Nothing Day, people join protests. Some people even cut up their credit cards. During the year, Buy Nothing groups also have events to trade and fix things. People bring things they already have to trade or to fix.

Is graffiti art or vandalism? Different people have different ideas. In many countries, the law says that writing or painting on public or private property is vandalism. Many street artists are stopped by the police. Some must pay a fine. Many city councils say it costs a lot of money to clean graffiti from buildings, buses, and trains.

What do people in the art world think about graffiti and street art? Today, more people say it is real art. There were big street art shows in galleries in Paris, London, and Los Angeles. In 2008, the American artist Elura Emerald organized a street art show at a gallery in New York. She defended street artists. She said they only express themselves and do not hurt anyone. She said we should enjoy and celebrate them.

Most people have four to six dreams every night after they are ten years old. That means they have about 2,000 dreams each year. When they are 80 years old, they might have had 140,000 dreams in their life. We forget most of our dreams - maybe 95 to 99 percent of them. But we still remember a few thousand dreams in our lifetime. So it is not surprising that sometimes we dream about something, and then a similar thing happens in real life. This happens by chance, especially when we dream about things that happen often in everyday life.

The story happens in the future, after North America was destroyed. The new country is called Panem. Panem has twelve poor districts. The rich Capitol rules them. The Capitol has all the power. Each district makes different things for the Capitol. District 12, where the story begins, gives all the coal to the country. There was also a thirteenth district, but it fought against the Capitol, and the Capitol destroyed it.

Wild animals often enter cities to find food. In Cape Town, South Africa, baboons come to areas where people live at the edge of the city to eat. They open trash bins. They eat fruit from gardens and orchards. Some baboons even go into people's houses. They take food from kitchen cupboards and fridges. Baboons can be dangerous. They attack pet animals. Many city residents do not want baboons in their area.

Many bridge accidents happen while people build the bridge. Engineers sometimes make mistakes, like a wrong calculation. Then the bridge falls under its own weight. This can kill workers on the bridge.

George Lucas was one of the first film directors to use the 17 steps of the 'hero's journey' to make his story. Usually, the hero lives a normal life. Then something happens and calls the hero to an adventure. This adventure changes everything. At the start of Star Wars, Luke lives a normal life with his aunt and uncle. He repairs robots. He finds a message from Princess Leia to Obi-Wan Kenobi inside the robot R2-D2. This message is the 'call to adventure.' It starts Luke's journey.

Scientists have another idea to stop an asteroid from hitting Earth: use a nuclear weapon to destroy it. This idea may sound like a movie story—after all, it was in the 1998 film Armageddon—but NASA has a real plan called HAMMER. Big rockets, weighing eight tons, would fly toward the asteroid and try to push it away. If the asteroid comes too close, the rockets would carry nuclear bombs to blow it up instead.

The hero first refuses the call to adventure. Then a mentor arrives and helps. The hero crosses the threshold and enters a special world. There, the hero passes tests, fights enemies, and meets friends to prepare for the biggest challenge. For Luke, Obi-Wan is the mentor, Han Solo and the robots R2D2 and C3PO are his friends, and Darth Vader is the enemy on the Death Star.

Some people do not use some items much. These items seem useless to them, but other people can use them. The internet helps online groups make money by sharing these items. People use websites and social media to buy and sell used things. Now people share directly with other people more easily than before. People call this the sharing economy.

In the 1700s and 1800s, two main ideas about dreams became popular. The first idea says that dreams show things our awake mind cannot see. Freud said that if we understand our dreams, we can understand our hidden feelings and the problems they cause. The second idea is the opposite. It says that dreams are only brain activity without order while the brain sorts memories and things from the day. When we wake up, we try to understand these mixed images and feelings and make a story from them.

I am a freelancer, so I work for myself. I like this because I can decide what I do and when I do it. I tried working from home, but I could not focus. There were too many distractions, like housework, making tea, and my family asking for help. Then I went to a café, but the Wi-Fi was not good, and I drank too much coffee. In the end, I rented a desk in a co-working space with five other freelancers. I enjoy getting dressed for work each morning and being able to focus in an office.

NASA needs money to build NEOCam, a 0.5-meter space telescope that uses infrared light to find asteroids. If NASA gets this funding, it can discover the remaining middle-sized near-Earth objects in about ten years. After it identifies these asteroids, the planetary defense team must still plan how to protect Earth from the most dangerous asteroids, called PHAs.

The 'buy nothing' idea is now popular with social media influencers. These influencers usually show clothes and makeup. They tell people to buy these things. Some YouTube stars tell their viewers to buy nothing for up to a year. Two friends in Canada tried to buy only food for one year. For the first three months, they stopped buying electronics, clothes, or things for the house. Next, they stopped paying for things like haircuts, eating in restaurants, or petrol for their cars. In one year, they saved $55,000.

Religion is important to Pi. His family is Hindu. He is curious about other religions. He makes friends with a Christian priest and a Muslim baker. Everyone is surprised. Pi says he is Hindu, Muslim, and Christian at the same time. His family and teachers ask him to choose one religion. Pi refuses. He says, 'I just want to love God.' After that, his family and teachers let him decide for himself about religion.

Some people think that writing down your dreams can help you have lucid dreams. A lucid dream is when you know you are dreaming, and you can change what happens. For example, you can make a scary dream feel safe, or you can control the story like a movie director. Then you are not just looking for the meaning of your dreams, but you are creating them. However, you might still want some dreams to happen naturally, so your subconscious can show you what is on your mind.

People give unwanted clothes to charity. They think this means they are not part of the clothing waste problem. But charity shops cannot sell all the clothes. Fast fashion goes out of style very quickly. It is often poor quality and hard to recycle. People do not want to buy it second-hand. So many clothes are thrown away. Many clothes that do not sell are sent to other countries. This causes more problems for people and for the environment.

Some adventurers want more than one trip, so they go from challenge to challenge. Meagan McGrath is from Canada. She climbed the highest mountain on each continent, rode her bike across Canada, and ran a long-distance race in the Sahara Desert, where it was 45°C. Her most impressive journey was a skiing trip to the South Pole. On the first day, she fell into a glacier and needed help to escape. Many people would have stopped then, but Meagan continued. After forty days, she reached the South Pole, pulling a sledge with her tent and food through freezing weather and ice storms.

Blek le Rat started painting rats on walls in Paris, his home city. Now, he wants people to think about different social problems. He paints pictures of homeless people in big cities. He hopes that people who live there will think about homelessness.

Some councils try to stop graffiti on random walls. They let artists paint in special areas. Taiwan has these areas, called graffiti zones. Artists can paint and write on walls there. In São Paulo, Brazil, the city council even lets some graffiti artists paint on the city's subway trains.

Faith47 is from Cape Town, South Africa. She paints big, colourful pictures of people and animals. She likes to explore many places. You can find her art on pavements, in empty factories, and on old cars. She likes that most street art is temporary. Rain, sun, and city cleaners remove it. For her, this shows that life always changes. Old things end, and new things begin.

Gabriela used to work in a place with high power distance. People respected the boss's power. Everyone knew their place. Leaders made the big decisions, and people did not question them. Her Swedish team was used to low power distance. Workers and bosses solved problems together. They made decisions as a team. Leaders acted like coaches or guides. They asked people to think for themselves. They accepted questions and disagreement.

Gabriela saw that she and her team came from different cultures. She asked them to talk openly about how she led them. The team was happy to share their thoughts. They said they were not used to being told what to do. They liked to decide things themselves and be creative. When Gabriela told them exactly what to do, they felt she did not trust them to do their jobs well. They saw that Gabriela felt hurt when they disagreed with her or tried to change her decisions. They explained that this was their normal way of working.

Os Gêmeos are twin brothers from São Paulo in Brazil. They are exactly the same because they are identical twins. They paint many different things. Sometimes they paint small tags. Sometimes they paint very big, colorful pictures of people on the walls of buildings. Their paintings are so big that they need special machines called cranes to help them reach high places. In 2007, they painted a whole castle in Scotland. They covered all the walls of the castle with their paint.

People have painted and written on walls for a very long time. In prehistoric times, people in Africa and Europe painted pictures of animals and people inside caves. Graffiti also appears on old buildings in Greece, Italy, Syria, and Iraq. In the Roman town of Pompeii, archaeologists found many examples of graffiti written in Latin. These messages talk about religion, politics, love, and even magic spells.

Have you ever dreamed of climbing Mount Everest or walking to the South Pole? Many people share this dream. Every year, thousands of people try to climb the world's highest mountains or walk across continents. Long ago, explorers used maps and compasses, but today's adventurers use modern tools like GPS and satellite phones. Many adventurers love nature and use their trips to teach people about environmental problems, while others want to help people in need and raise money for charities.

DART is the Double Asteroid Redirection Test. Scientists will test DART on the small moon of an asteroid called Didymos. This moon, known as Didymoon, is 150 meters wide. It orbits a larger asteroid that is 800 meters wide. Scientists hope DART will hit Didymoon and change its orbit enough for Earth-based telescopes to detect.

Katniss Everdeen is sixteen years old. She lost her father in a mining accident and must feed her family. She hunts in the woods near District 12 with her friend Gale and becomes very good with a bow and arrow. One day, people choose her younger sister, Prim, as a tribute. Katniss volunteers to go instead. Another tribute from District 12 is a boy named Peeta. Katniss soon has a complicated relationship with him.

Writing about your dreams helps you remember more details. Think about the people and places in the dream because they can add meaning. After a week, you will be surprised by how much you have written. Then you can connect your dreams to events and feelings in your daily life.

In the past, people built many bridges from wood. Wood bridges burned easily. Old train bridges had this problem a lot. Sparks from steel wheels on steel tracks sometimes started fires. These sparks could make a bridge catch fire and burn down.

We do not know exactly how street art will change in the future, but new trends are starting. Many street artists are young people who paint in their neighborhoods. However, more street artists now travel and create art around the world. They also use the internet to talk and share photos of their work. The art world is giving more respect to street art as a real art form. We cannot predict the future of street art, but we know it will stay.

Suzanne Collines always feels upset when she watches news about wars. When she was a child, her father was a pilot in the US Air Force. He fought in the Vietnam War. Her mother tried to protect her. She did not tell Suzanne what was happening in the war. But Suzanne still saw war news on TV. She knew her dad was there. It was very scary for her.

PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC) held a global survey. They collected answers from over 40,000 millennials (born between 1983 and 1993) and other adults. People answered questions about workplace culture, communication, working styles, pay, career development, and work–life balance. Deloitte also held a global survey with more than 10,000 millennials. They asked about threats and opportunities in the complex world of work.

Erik Weihenmayer is an adventurer from the United States. He goes on many adventures. He rode a bike across the deserts of Morocco. He kayaked through the Grand Canyon. He climbed Mount Everest. He has been blind since he was 13. He encourages people with disabilities to live active lives. He takes groups of young blind people on climbing trips.

Websites and apps let people make money quickly. Before, many busy parents did not set up a stall at a local market to sell old baby things. Now, parents can use online marketplaces to sell baby clothes that their children wore only a few times. The children are now too big for these clothes. Parents can also sell pushchairs and other baby equipment. This helps parents get some money back.

Pi and Richard Parker stay in a lifeboat for 227 days. They feel hunger, sickness, and great tiredness. They face big storms and the very hot sun of the Pacific. They survive. Sometimes Pi finds comfort in his three religions. Other times he feels very lonely and very sad. At last, the Mexican coast appears far away. Then everything changes. To know the ending, you can read the book and see what happens to Pi and Richard Parker when they see land.

Chloe came home from school. She made a cup of coffee and took it to her bedroom. She had some homework, but she could do it later. She wanted a quiet hour before her parents came home and filled the house with talking, television, or her dad's jazz music while he cooked dinner. Chloe also liked this time because she could play with her pet rats.

In 2010, NASA's team found and wrote down 90% of the near-Earth asteroids that are 1 kilometer wide. These objects are called near-Earth objects (NEOs). They can be as big as mountains. A NEO is any object that comes within 50 million kilometers of Earth's path around the Sun. NASA thinks about 50 of these big asteroids are still not recorded. NASA knows about 887 of them and says none of these are a serious danger to Earth.

Auggie decided to go to school. He started his first day. He felt very nervous, like any new student. Because his face looked different, the day was very hard. No one wanted to sit next to him. He saw kids stare at him. He heard kids whisper about him. Luckily, he made two friends: Jack from his class and Summer at lunch. The first day was not the only hard day. Soon he learned that some classmates did not want to touch him. They were afraid they could catch 'the plague.' During the year, he had good days and bad days. Then a sudden, very bad event at a school camp changed everything.

The two men looked to the north end of the land. The land was very big. They could hardly see the fences. Even if a teenage boy felt bored and wanted to break the rules, he could not get away by walking. Sam looked at the biggest horse. It kicked the ground with its heavy hooves. He wondered if the boy could ride a horse. A good rider could get into a lot of trouble out here, far from other people. But a boy who did not know horses could get into even more trouble if he tried to run away from his father.

Over 4,000 climbers aged 13 to 80 reached the top of Mount Everest. Climbing high mountains in very cold weather and strong storms is still very dangerous, but the best climbers now look for new challenges. Gerlinde Kaltenbrunner is from Austria. She fell in love with mountain climbing when she was a teenager. After she left school, she worked as a nurse. She kept climbing in her free time.

Gerlinde climbed Everest. After that, she decided to climb all fourteen 8,000-metre mountains in the world. She wants a bigger challenge. She climbs without oxygen tanks. This is risky. Low oxygen at the top of high mountains can hurt the brain and the body. Gerlinde uses her fame to support a charity. The charity helps poor children and orphans in Nepal.

Look around your home. We buy many things, but we do not use all of them well. For example, we buy a thick wool coat because it looks trendy, but we live in a tropical country. We put away our old smartphone when we buy the newest model. We use the car only on weekends. We turn the guest room into a storeroom.

In the past, in many cultures, people thought dreams could tell the future. They believed gods sent dreams to give people knowledge. Even today, many people remember a dream about an event, a place, or a person. Later, they see the same thing happen in real life.

Some of the biggest and most expensive transport projects in the world are bridges. Bridges are important. They let cars, trucks, and trains cross rivers and valleys. They can also go over other roads. So bridges are a very important part of building roads and train lines. People check bridges carefully, especially after a bridge falls down.

Gabriela felt frustrated for weeks. She emailed her Swedish manager about problems with her team. The manager asked, 'Is your team still working well?' and 'What do you think can help you work better with your team?' Gabriela thought his answer was not clear. She felt he did not handle the problem well.

Some dogs live in packs. They have learned that people give more food to small, cute dogs. So the pack sends the small dogs to beg for food for everyone. Some dogs even use the city metro. They ride the train to go from one part of the city to another. Scientists do not know how the dogs know when to get off. Maybe the dogs use their strong sense of smell. They may know the smells of their favorite places. Or maybe they know the station names they hear on the train. Now, metro passengers often see dogs on the trains. The dogs travel quietly, and most local people do not notice them.

Ed Stafford is from the UK. He is the first person to walk the entire Amazon River. He started at a small stream in the Andes mountains of Peru. After two years and four months, he reached the river's mouth in Brazil. He walked 6,000 kilometres. The Amazon rainforest has poisonous snakes, crocodiles and jaguars, so he was always in danger. He was lucky to survive with only thousands of mosquito and ant bites.

In the UK, people spend more than £1000 on new clothes each year. This is about four percent of the money they earn. This sounds like a small amount, but it creates two big problems for our society and the environment. First, many people use credit cards to buy these clothes. Now, every adult in the UK owes about £670 to credit card companies. This is 66% of the money they spend on clothes. Also, people buy clothes with money they don't have. And they buy things they don't need. The UK throws away 300,000 tons of clothes every year. Most of these clothes go to rubbish dumps.

Ed could not finish his walk without technology. He used a radio to ask people in the rainforest for food and permission to cross their land. Many people met him and guided him through the hardest areas. While he walked, Ed wrote a blog about his daily experiences. He used media attention to protest against destroying the rainforest and to raise money for environmental and children's charities in Brazil and Peru.

Many businesses see that sharing can make money. They want to use things that people are not using. One popular model is this: a company makes a website or app. The app connects customers with people who offer a product or a service. Airbnb is one example. It is a middleman. It helps people rent out empty rooms or homes to guests and earn money. Uber is another example. It lets people use their own cars as taxis. Drivers can make extra money in their free time.

Zoos help endangered animals with international breeding programs. Some rare animals cannot find mates in the wild, and they face threats from hunters, loss of habitat, or predators. Zoos give them a safe place to live and have babies. When numbers of certain animals get too low, they can become too genetically similar. Breeding programs protect them by releasing zoo-born animals into the wild to increase genetic variety.

These accidents are very rare. Boats and trains can make a bridge fall down for different reasons. A train can make a bridge fall down because of its high speed when it hits. A big boat can make a bridge fall down because it is very heavy, even when it moves slowly. The best way to stop bridge failures is to plan ahead. New tools can find weak parts in a bridge. Safer workplaces and better designs can also help. These steps can reduce these bad accidents.

Pi feels very afraid of the animals and jumps into the ocean. Then he remembers there are sharks around him and realises he must climb back into the lifeboat. One by one, the animals in the lifeboat kill and eat each other, until only Pi and the tiger stay alive. Pi names the tiger Richard Parker. The tiger is seasick and does not want to eat Pi right away.

Pi is 16. A new government wins the election. His parents do not support it. They worry about the future. They close their zoo. They decide to move to Canada. They sell some animals to zoos in North America. The family travels to Canada by ship. They take other animals with them. A terrible storm hits the ship. The ship sinks. Pi's family and the sailors drown. Pi stays alive. He is in a lifeboat with a hyena, a zebra, an orangutan, and a very big tiger.

The Hunger Games is a very popular book for teenagers and young adults. Suzanne Collins, an American writer, wrote it. The book came out in 2008. Publishers translated it into 26 languages. People around the world bought millions of copies. It was the first young readers book to sell more than one million e-books. The Hunger Games is also a big Hollywood movie. The movie is very successful too. It earned 152.5 million dollars in its first weekend in North America only.

Dreams might be our brain organizing thoughts from the day, but in dreams these thoughts become symbols. When we are awake, our thoughts are mostly words in our head, like we are talking to ourselves. But when we sleep, the part of our brain that controls language becomes less active, and the part that controls emotions becomes more active.

Good relationships help us feel happy. A study found that most happy people have close relationships with family and friends. They spend time with them often. You also need at least one person you can talk to about your personal feelings. This is called self-disclosure. One close person is enough if you also have other friends. It is not enough to have many friends only for fun or small talk about music or football. A deep connection is very important. Some people need to learn to listen well to build stronger relationships.

Carol Dweck, a psychologist who studies 'growth mindset,' says the brain can change. We can learn new skills or talents even if we are not good at them at first. Many people praise only the final result, for example, 'You notice details well' or 'You are good at organizing events.' But studies show that focusing on how we do things—praising effort, trying new methods, and finding solutions—helps us develop new skills and improve our talents.

The rover checks the air around it from time to time. In 2014, it found methane in the air. Methane is a simple organic molecule and a main part of natural gas. Methane lasts only a few hundred years. So something on Mars adds new methane. NASA says Mars lets out thousands of tons of methane at a time. The methane level goes up and down with the seasons, like the planet is breathing.

Professor Dweck, a psychologist at Stanford University, gave some ten-year-old children difficult problems when she started her work. One group of children were very positive. They liked challenges and knew they could get better. Professor Dweck called this a 'growth mindset.' These children thought about what they could learn and do in the future. But the other group of children felt people were judging them and thought they failed. This was a 'fixed mindset.' They thought they could not get better. Some children said they might cheat later. Other children would look for people who did worse than them. This made them feel better.

Horror films like empty places. They might show an abandoned hospital, a scary empty house, or a ghost town with no people. These lonely places make us think. We ask what life was like there. We ask why people left. They are very quiet, and the quiet can be scary. These places also help horror film directors. Viewers can believe there is no mobile phone signal there.

In horror movies, the basement in any house is scary. Often, someone hides there, or a bad person keeps tools there. The basement is always dark and often wet. You can only go down very narrow stairs to the basement. Even when there is nothing down there, the basement still makes people afraid.

Gary Collins was a police officer on holiday. He watched the London riots on TV. He recognised some people. He ended his holiday and went to help the police. He watched CCTV videos for six months. He identified 190 people, sometimes only by their eyes. His help was very important to the investigation. The police had 200,000 hours of video, but the face-recognition computer found only one person.

I think it is very interesting to think about how we will change and grow as humans by adding technology to our bodies. Think about putting a small computer in our brain! Soon we will be able to do this. This will help us be better at math, see and hear better, and remember more things. This idea will become normal in the future.

The talk was very interesting. The speaker made some very good points. Children copy their parents. Parents use social media while they cook dinner or wait at a red light. Teenagers see this. Then they also text while they do homework. The speaker also said that people want to be in more than one place at the same time. They change between real-life talk and online chat. I see this with my teenage daughter and her friends. They plan to meet. Then they sit together in silence. Each one chats online with someone else.

Some news stories make us think the world is getting more violent. But there is some good news too. From the end of World War II to 1990, there were 30 wars. Each of these wars killed more than 100,000 people. Today there are still civil wars, but most countries live more peacefully than before. Terrorism has increased a lot in the last few years. Since World War II, wars have killed more civilians than soldiers. Even so, not all the numbers are bad for civilians. People are about nine times more likely to die from violent crime than from political conflict. The global murder rate went down a little. It was 8 per 100,000 people in 2000. It was about 5.3 in 2015.

Wasfia supports human rights. She has spent her life on this work. She saw many international aid projects in Bangladesh. These projects taught and trained women and girls. But when the projects ended, the women got nothing. Wasfia decided that Bangladesh needed to help itself. She joined her two passions: mountain climbing and human rights. She wants to change how people see women in her country. She started climbing while she worked on aid campaigns in Tibet and Nepal. Bangladesh is a flat country by the sea, so most people there have never seen a mountain. Her work is helping. People in Bangladesh and around the world are paying attention.

Most people think that developing countries are in a very bad situation. They think people suffer from extreme poverty. They think dictators control these countries. They think there is little hope for change. But this is not true. A big change is happening. In the past 20 years, more than 700 million people have increased their income and left poverty. Every year, six million fewer children die from disease. Millions more girls go to school. Millions more people have clean water.

Many managers place negative feedback between two positive comments. However, if they do this too often, employees may think the positive comments simply hide the negatives. Managers should give positive feedback to support and encourage good work, not just to soften criticism.

I belong to a group that wants to stop killer robots. Do not only imagine scary movie robots like the Terminator. Today, the military already uses drones, gun turrets, and sentry robots that kill with little human control. The next step is autonomous 'murderbots.' They follow orders but decide who to kill on their own. I believe this is wrong and dangerous for everyone. We must be careful about what tasks we allow machines to do.

More people learn English than all other languages together. English is also spoken in more countries than any other language. But Chinese has the most native speakers by far. There is no clear connection between how many native speakers a language has and how many people learn it. However, there is a stronger connection between the number of learners and how many countries speak that language.

Your manager stops you. She says she needs to talk about your work on the recent project. You worry all weekend. You think you did something wrong. On Monday morning, you go to her office. She begins by saying you did a good job on the project. You wonder if this is the usual 'feedback sandwich.' You know this way: say something nice, say the real problem, say something nice again.

'Born in the USA' is a fast rock album that makes people tap their feet. The music sounds good, and the lyrics have a lot of feeling. It shows another side of the American dream: some people work very hard but do not become rich or famous, so they feel sad or angry. For example, 'Glory Days' is about small-town people who remember their happy youth, and 'Downbound Train' is about a young man who loses his job and struggles in life. We can imagine these stories come from the singer's friends or from his own life. If he had not become a star, he might also live like this. The album shows that 'The Boss' is very special and very talented.

Lewis wants more parts of the ocean to be protected. He hopes this will grow from 3% to 10%. This will help fix problems made by people. For example, people catch too many fish, make the water dirty, and throw trash. On his trips, Lewis saw these problems himself. He swam over coral that was white because the water was too hot. He also saw the bottom of the Red Sea. It looked empty, like a desert, with no animals or plants, only plastic trash. Pugh thinks nature can get healthy again if we give it room. But we don't have much time. If we don't start to protect the ocean, we will soon have a very big problem we cannot fix.

Terrie Sharp is a best-selling writer. She tells very good stories. She won the Olive Crime Writer Award two times. She was born in a part of Glasgow with a lot of crime. She learned to keep quiet and stay out of trouble. She even learned to open a car door with a knife. She used this knowledge only to write her books. Now she is not quiet. She is on daytime TV shows, like Police Today. She also talks at writing events around the UK.

Do things get worse every day? Is progress impossible? In his book Enlightenment Now, Steven Pinker looks at human progress and finds good news. People live longer. People are healthier, freer, and happier. But there is a problem, he says. Some people attack reason and science. Some leaders and people on TV or online use fear and anger. They push people to think 'us versus them.' They say nothing can change. They tell people not to trust others. This can hurt important systems. It can harm democracy and cooperation between countries. The damage can be hard to fix.

In older horror movies, the main characters often could not call for help or call the police when they were in trouble. Now, mobile phones make that less believable. So, filmmakers usually show no phone signal to keep the tension. If you are a hero in a horror movie, you will almost certainly lose phone coverage right when you need to call for help. Or your phone battery will die at that exact moment. Or both.

In the 1950s, banana farmers in Central America had a big problem. Their best-selling banana, the Gros Michel (Big Mike), was dying. Now the same thing is happening to the Cavendish, the banana that came after it. The Gros Michel had thick skin and a sweet taste, and it was easy to send far. It was the main banana on farms in Central America. United Fruit was the main grower in South America then, and it sold bananas to other countries. The company grew bananas in a fast and cheap way. It cut pieces from plant stems to make new plants instead of using seeds. It planted the bananas very close together.

Most spiders have venom. They use it to stun or kill prey. They do not want to hurt people. Only 25 spider species have venom that can harm people. Spider bites can hurt, but they are rarely deadly. Australia has a spider called the Sydney funnel-web. Since 1981, anti-venom has stopped deaths from this spider. Be careful with hairy spiders like tarantulas. When they feel danger, they throw tiny, itchy hairs into the air. These hairs can get into your skin or eyes and cause irritation.

This was a common story in horror movies in the late 1900s. A group of teenagers have fun at the start. In the end, everyone dies except one girl. At first, the girl is innocent, shy, and not strong. By the end, she is very strong and very good at solving problems. The last girl usually wins.

We want to know where our complex language came from. We must look at our brains. Our brains are different from animal brains. This is not just about brain size. We need to know what our brains can do, and when and why they changed. We have few clues about this. Old tools from our ancestors do not tell us how they spoke. But we can see one thing in old human bones: how their mouth, throat, and tongue changed. By 100,000 years ago, humans could make complex sounds. Before that, scientists can only guess if early humans used simple sounds to talk.

People, not nature, tell us that girls should like arts and languages. They tell us that boys should study maths and physics. Children do not see many women who work in science. Cartoons and stories often show the scientist, the very smart inventor, or the brave astronaut as a man. Many people think scientists are nerdy, not good at talking, and lonely. They think science is far from real life. The media gives us these ideas, but they are not true. These ideas can make girls feel that science is not for them. Girls may think science is not interesting or not a good job. If girls see more good examples of women in science, they get more confidence and feel welcome in those subjects.

The Scallion is printed every week and given out for free in faculty buildings. Around 10,000 students read it. Students write and produce the newspaper. A survey shows that students and staff value it for entertainment, culture, and work experience. Printing costs are high. Some students cannot get it easily because they must go to the university to find a copy. Also, many copies become litter on campus.

At Girox Foods, about 12% of our employees leave each year. This number may not look high, but the industry average is only 7%. The main goal of this report is to find out why our employees are motivated at work and suggest ways to help them feel happier, so they choose to stay with the company.

I agree with the speaker. When we spend more time online, we can feel more alone. For my generation, this is not a big problem. We lived many years without technology. We can be alone, and we know it is OK. But many people under 20 years old are different. They are always sending messages and talking online. They do not have quiet time alone. They may not learn to enjoy their own company. They also learn to talk by writing messages that they can change. This makes it hard to learn real conversation. In real life, you talk to the person in front of you right away, and you cannot change your words.

Do not always give a negative comment after a good comment. If you always put good and bad comments together, people stop caring about the good ones. The good words can feel less important, and people may ignore them. Sometimes, give only positive feedback. Say what the person did well, and stop there. Try not to add advice every time.

Your dreams might show you all kinds of insights into things that you didn't realise you were thinking about. Common dreams like being able to fly or falling, your teeth falling out or having no clothes on in a public place probably mean something similar in most people. But the key to knowing exactly what they mean to you is to connect them to the events and feelings in your daily life.

One of the most interesting cases of wild animals living in a city are the wild dogs of Moscow. In Moscow, there are approximately 35,000 wild dogs living on the streets. Some of the dogs were born wild, while others are pets that have been left behind by their owners. Some dogs live alone and others live in packs. In 2010, scientists studied the dogs and discovered that the dogs have adapted very successfully to city life. They have learned that it is safer to cross the street with people and some dogs appear to understand traffic lights.

Wonder is the first novel by New York author RJ Palacio. She explains on her website that she got the idea for the book after seeing a girl with a facial deformity on the street. Wonder became a bestseller in the United States and won several awards. Many schools use it to discuss bullying, friendship, and what it means to be different. A movie version is being made, and many people, including me, are excited to see what RJ Palacio will write next.

Chloe has two pet rats, Zena and Roxy. Chloe knows they're not typical pets and she has lost count of the times she's calmly tried to explain to people that rats aren't dirty. They make fantastic pets if you look after them correctly. But she understands why people react badly. She didn't like rats either until her friend Martin showed her his pet rats and she saw how loving and intelligent they were. Last year, when one of Martin's rats had babies, Chloe decided she'd like to have two of them.

Cape Town can be dangerous for baboons. Some get hurt or killed in car accidents. Others get electric shocks when they play with electric cables. Baboons are an endangered species. So, to save them and reduce problems with people, the city council has hired a team of Baboon Monitors. These monitors chase baboons out of cities. They also catch them and let them go in the countryside. This plan has worked a little. However, it is hard to stop baboons from coming back to the city when they find easy food there.

I work for a global IT company. Its main office is in the USA, so I do all my work online from home. This means I don't waste time commuting or making small talk with colleagues. My work is project-based, and this flexibility is very valuable to me. It means I can easily take time off when my children need me for school plays, or when I need to make a dentist's appointment. The downside is that without clear office hours, I tend to work late into the evening. Sometimes I even skip dinner to finish a task.

In the 1990s, graffiti continued but there was also an explosion in street art around the world. Some artists wanted to make political points and produced art that tried to make people think about war, unfairness and discrimination. Other street artists were more concerned with producing beautiful, attractive work. In South America, many street artists went to work in poor areas adding colour, life and beauty to grey, city walls.

Social media, magazines and shop windows show people many things to buy every day, and British consumers are buying more clothes and shoes than ever before. Online shopping makes it easy for customers to buy without thinking, while major brands offer such cheap clothes that they can be used like throwaway items – worn two or three occasions and then thrown away.

Sam narrowed his eyes against the sun and looked at the far dust trail kicked up by the car as it drove up to the Big House. The horses kicked and swished their tails at the flies. They did not care that their owner was visiting for the first time in ten months. Sam waited. Mr Carter only came out here when he had to, and that was fine with Sam. The more he stayed out of his boss's way, the longer he would keep his job. Mr Carter rubbed the sweat off the back of his neck. The damp spots on his shirt ran together like shapes on a map. His skin was already turning red in the June sun. Otherwise, he had the indoor look of a man who made money while other people did the work.

Many people living in Berlin, Germany complained that shooting pigs was too cruel. Hunters and animal lovers had angry arguments about this. Because of the protests, the city council decided to use more peaceful methods against the pigs. Instead of shooting them, they built fences and made it against the law to feed the pigs. We will see if this plan works, but it might be a fight they cannot win. This is because warmer winters mean there are more pigs now than before.

One important inspiration for the book The Hunger Games comes from Suzanne's love of classical Greek myths. When she was a child, one of her favorite stories was about Theseus and the Minotaur. In this story, the city of Athens is ruled by Crete, but the Athenians rebel. As punishment, Minos, the king of Crete, forces the people of Athens to send seven boys and seven girls to Crete every year. The young people are thrown into a maze called the Labyrinth and are eaten by a monster called the Minotaur that lives there. But one of the young people, named Theseus, fights the Minotaur and kills it. Suzanne sees Katniss Everdeen as a future version of Theseus.

By bringing people and animals together, zoos have the potential to educate the public about conservation issues and inspire people to protect animals and their habitats. Some zoos provide a safe place for animals which have been badly treated in circuses, or pets which have been left behind. Zoos also carry out important research into subjects like animal behaviour and how to cure illnesses.

In contrast to consumerism, a different trend is emerging: the 'Buy Nothing' trend. The idea started in Canada in the early 1990s and then spread to the USA. There, it became a protest against too much spending and consumption on Black Friday and Cyber Monday during the Thanksgiving weekend. On Buy Nothing Day, people organize different kinds of protests and cut up their credit cards. All year round, Buy Nothing groups organize the exchange and repair of things they already own.

Is graffiti art or vandalism? It depends on your point of view, but in many countries, writing or painting on public or private property is considered vandalism. Many street artists have been stopped by the police, and some had to pay fines. Many city councils complain about the high cost of cleaning graffiti from buildings, buses, and trains.

What does the art world think of graffiti and street art? Recently, there has been more and more understanding of its value as an art form. There have been major exhibitions of street art in galleries in Paris, London and Los Angeles. The American artist Elura Emerald organised a street art exhibition at a New York gallery in 2008. She defended street artists. She said, 'Artists who paint on the street are merely expressing themselves, not hurting anyone. They should be appreciated and celebrated'.

If most people have four to six dreams every night after the age of ten, that's as many as 2,000 dreams per year. So, by the time they reach 80 years old the average person might have had 140,000 dreams. Even if we forget 95–99 per cent of our dreams, that's still a few thousand remembered dreams across a person's life. It's not too difficult to believe that, by chance, a dream event is followed by a real-life event that's similar to it, especially if the subject of the dream is something that happens often in everyday life.

The Hunger Games takes place in the future, after the destruction of North America. The country is called Panem and is made up of twelve poor districts governed by the rich Capitol. The Capitol holds absolute power over the nation. Each district is responsible for producing different things for the Capitol. District 12, where the story begins, provides all the coal for the country. There used to be a thirteenth district but they fought against the Capitol in the past and were destroyed.

Wild animals often come into cities to look for food. In Cape Town, South Africa, baboons have started visiting neighborhoods on the outskirts of the city to find something to eat. They open trash cans and eat fruit from gardens and orchards. Some brave baboons even enter people's houses and take food from kitchen cupboards and refrigerators! Baboons can be aggressive and have attacked many pets, so many city residents do not want them around.

A large number of bridge accidents occur during the construction of the bridge itself. These accidents are often due to an error made by the engineers, such as a wrong calculation. The bridge falls down under its own weight, and this can be deadly for the workers on it at the time.

George Lucas was one of the early film directors to directly base his story on the 17 stages of the hero's journey. Typically the hero starts the story living an ordinary life, but something happens that calls them to an adventure that changes everything. At the beginning of Star Wars, Luke lives an ordinary life with his aunt and uncle, repairing robots. When he finds Princess Leia's message to Obi-Wan Kenobi inside the robot R2D2, it is 'the call to adventure' that starts the hero on his journey.

Another idea to protect Earth from a dangerous space rock coming towards us is to destroy it with a nuclear bomb. This might sound like a story from a movie, and it was actually used in the 1998 movie Armageddon, but HAMMER (a special space program) is a real plan from the American space agency. Large missiles weighing eight tons would be shot at the space rock to try to push it away from Earth. If the space rock was too close to Earth for this plan to work, the missiles would carry nuclear bombs to destroy it completely.

According to Campbell, the hero first refuses the call to adventure. But then, a mentor appears and helps him. So, the hero decides to 'cross the threshold' and go into the 'special world' where the adventure takes place. The next step is to pass tests, fight enemies, and meet friends. While doing this, the hero prepares to face his biggest challenge. For Luke, the mentor is, of course, Obi-Wan. His friends are Han Solo and the robots R2D2 and C3PO. And the enemy is Darth Vader, in the special world of the Death Star.

Some items that people do not use much may seem useless to some, but they can be valuable to others. Thanks to the internet, online communities have found ways to earn money by sharing these items. Websites and social media groups make it easy to buy and sell used goods. Today, sharing directly between people is easier than ever. This is called the sharing economy.

In the 18th and 19th centuries, two main ideas about dreams became popular. One idea said that what we see in dreams stands for something hidden from our conscious mind. Freud believed that if we understand our dreams, we can understand our hidden feelings and the problems they cause. The other idea was the opposite. It said that dreams are just random brain activity while the brain sorts memories and events from the day. When we wake up, we try to make sense of these random images and feelings and turn them into a kind of story.

I am a freelancer and work for myself. This is great because I can decide what I do and how I spend my time. At first, I worked from home, but I found it very hard to concentrate. There were too many distractions: housework that needed doing, another cup of tea, and family members who also wanted my attention. Next, I tried working in a nearby café, but the Wi-Fi was not good, and I drank too much coffee. In the end, I decided to rent a desk in a co-working space with five other freelancers. I liked getting dressed for work in the morning and being able to focus in an office environment.

Whether NASA can find the remaining medium-sized NEOs depends on whether it gets money to build NEOCam, a 0.5-meter space telescope that would use infrared light to spot asteroids. If NASA receives funding, it can probably reach its goal in ten years. Once the asteroids are found, the planetary defense team must still figure out how to protect Earth from the truly worrying asteroids, called PHAs.

The 'buy nothing' trend has now reached influencers on social media who usually share posts of clothes and make-up that they recommend for people to buy. Some YouTube stars now encourage their watchers not to buy anything at all for periods as long as a year. Two friends in Canada spent a year working towards buying only food. For the first three months they learned how to live without buying electrical goods, clothes or things for the house. For the next stage, they gave up services, for example haircuts, eating out at restaurants or buying petrol for their cars. In one year, they'd saved $55,000.

Religion is important to Pi. Though his family is Hindu, he is curious about other religions and he makes friends with a Christian priest and a Muslim baker. To everyone's surprise, Pi declares himself to be at the same time Hindu, Muslim and Christian. When his family and teachers ask him to choose just one religion, Pi refuses, saying 'I just want to love God'. From that moment, his family and teachers decide to let him make his own mind up about religion.

Some people think that writing down dreams can help open the mind to lucid dreaming. Lucid dreams are dreams where you know that you are dreaming. In these dreams, you can also make choices to change what happens in the dream. For example, you might change a bad dream into a safe dream. Or you can control the dream story like a movie director. Instead of just trying to understand what dreams mean, you create them yourself. But you might still want to have some normal dreams that let your mind show you what you are thinking about.

People might not realise they are part of the throwaway clothes problem because they give their unwanted clothes to charities. But charity shops can't sell all those unwanted clothes. 'Fast fashion' goes out of fashion as quickly as it came in and is often too poor quality to recycle; people don't want to buy it second-hand. Huge quantities end up being thrown away, and a lot of clothes that charities can't sell are sent abroad, causing even more economic and environmental problems.

Some modern adventurers are not happy with just one amazing trip. They go from challenge to challenge. Meagan McGrath from Canada has climbed the highest mountain on each continent. She has also cycled across Canada and ran a long distance race in the Sahara Desert when it was 45°C. But perhaps her most incredible journey was skiing to the South Pole. On the first day, she fell into a glacier and needed to be rescued. Many people would have given up at that point, but Meagan decided to continue. She reached the South Pole forty days later. She had pulled a sled with a tent and all her food behind her through freezing conditions and ice storms.

Blek le Rat started out painting rats on the walls of his home city, Paris. Nowadays, he tries to make people think about different social issues and problems. He paints pictures of homeless people in big cities to encourage local people to think about the problem of homelessness.

In some areas, councils have tried to encourage artists not to paint graffiti randomly on walls by allowing them to work in designated areas. Taiwan is one such place and there are 'graffiti zones' where artists are free to paint and write on walls. In São Paulo in Brazil, the city council has even allowed some graffiti artists to paint on the city's subway trains.

Faith47 is from Cape Town in South Africa. She paints big, colourful pictures of people and animals and likes to explore different locations. Her work is seen on sidewalks, in empty factories and on cars left behind. She likes the fact that most street art is temporary and will soon be removed by weather or cleaners from the city council. For her, this reflects how life is full of change with its cycle of endings and new beginnings.

In her previous workplace, Gabriela was used to a high power distance culture where power and authority are valued and everyone has their rightful place. In such a culture, leaders make the big decisions and are not often challenged. Her Swedish team, however, were used to working in a low power distance culture where employees often work together with their bosses to find solutions and make decisions. Here, leaders act as coaches or guides who encourage independent thought and expect to be challenged.

When Gabriela noticed the cultural differences between her and her team, she took the initiative and had an open talk with them about their feelings about her leadership. The team was happy to be asked. They said they were not used to being told what to do. They preferred more room to take initiative and be creative. When Gabriela told them exactly what she expected, they felt she did not trust them to do their jobs well. They noticed that Gabriela took it personally when they questioned or changed her decisions, and they explained that they had always worked this way.

Os Gêmeos are identical twin brothers from São Paulo. They paint everything, from tags to huge, colorful pictures of people on the sides of buildings. Their artworks are often so big that they need cranes to help them work. In 2007, they covered a whole castle in Scotland with paint.

Throughout history, people have painted and written on walls. In prehistoric times, people in Africa and Europe painted pictures of animals and humans in caves. Graffiti has been found on buildings at ancient sites in Greece, Italy, Syria, and Iraq. In the Roman city of Pompeii, archaeologists have discovered many examples of graffiti written in Latin. These include religious, political, and romantic messages, and even some magic spells!

Have you ever dreamed of climbing Mount Everest or walking to the South Pole? If yes, you are not alone. Every year, thousands of people try to climb the world's highest mountains or cross entire continents. Unlike past explorers who used maps and compasses, modern adventurers rely on technology such as GPS and satellite phones. Many of them love nature and use their journeys to raise awareness of environmental issues, while others want to help people in need and collect donations for charity.

The first project is DART, which means the Double Asteroid Redirection Test. The plan is to test DART on a moon of an asteroid called Didymos. This moon, named 'Didymoon,' is 150 meters wide. It moves around its main asteroid, which is 800 meters wide. Hopefully, when DART hits Didymoon, it will move the moon enough from its normal path so that telescopes on Earth can see the change.

The main character of the story is a sixteen-year-old girl named Katniss Everdeen. She lost her father in a mining accident and now she must take care of her family. She hunts with her friend Gale in the forests around District 12 and becomes very good with a bow and arrow. When her younger sister, Prim, is chosen as one of the Tributes, Katniss volunteers to go instead of her. The other Tribute from District 12 is a boy named Peeta, and Katniss soon finds herself in a complicated relationship with him.

Writing about your dreams will mean you start to remember more details about the dream. So, think about the people and place where the dream happened, as they might add to the meaning too. Over the period of a week you'll be surprised how much you've written down. Now you can start connecting your dreams to the events and feelings in your daily life.

Historically, more bridges were made of wood, which meant they were much more likely to catch fire. This was especially true for old railway bridges, where sparks from the steel wheels and tracks sometimes caused a bridge to catch fire and burn down completely.

It is impossible to know how street art will develop in the future but certain trends are emerging. While most street artists are young people who paint in their city or neighbourhood, more and more street artists are travelling and working around the globe. Other artists are using the internet to talk to each other and share photos of their work. Also, the art world is giving more credit to street art as a real art form. Although we don't know what will happen to street art in the future, we can be sure that it is here to stay!

Suzanne Collines has always felt news programmes of wars upsetting. When she was a child, her father was a pilot in the US Air Force and he fought in Vietnam. Her mother tried to protect her by not telling her what was happening in the war. But she still saw news programmes about the war and knew that her dad was there. It was a very frightening experience for her.

PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC) did a worldwide survey with more than 40,000 people. They asked Millennials (people born between 1983 and 1993) and non-Millennials about workplace culture, communication, work styles, pay, career development, and work-life balance. Deloitte also did a separate worldwide survey with more than 10,000 Millennials. They studied how Millennials see the threats and opportunities in today's complicated work world.

Erik Weihenmayer from the United States is a person who does many adventures. He's ridden a bike through the deserts of Morocco, kayaked through the Grand Canyon and climbed Everest. Amazingly, Erik has been blind since the age of 13. Apart from his travels, he tries to encourage people with disabilities to live active lives and takes groups of young blind people on climbing trips.

Open online platforms are providing a chance for people to make some quick money. For example, busy parents before might not have cared about setting up a stall at the local market or car boot sale to sell their children's old equipment. But with online markets, parents are now able to sell on those hardly worn baby clothes that their children have outgrown. They can also sell the expensive pushchairs and baby equipment they have invested in, so as to put some cash back into their pockets.

Pi and Richard Parker spend 227 days in the lifeboat. They suffer from hunger, illness, and extreme tiredness. They face strong storms and the burning heat of the Pacific sun, but they somehow survive. Sometimes Pi finds comfort in his three religions. But at other times, he feels overwhelmed by loneliness and a feeling of hopelessness. Finally, the Mexican coast appears on the horizon, and everything changes. It would be a shame to tell you the ending, so you have to read the book yourself to find out what happens to Pi and Richard Parker once they see land.

Chloe arrived home from school, made herself a cup of coffee and took it up to her bedroom. She had some homework to do, but that could wait for later. She wanted to enjoy the quiet hour before her parents arrived home. Then the house would fill with the evening sounds of chatter, television, or her dad listening to his beloved jazz while he cooked dinner. She liked this time of day too because she could play with her pet rats.

By 2010, NASA had found and recorded information about 90% of the large asteroids near Earth. These asteroids are 1 kilometre wide. They are called 'near-Earth objects', or NEOs. These NEOs are as big as mountains. They can come within 50 million kilometres of Earth's path in space. NASA still needs to find about 50 more of these large asteroids. However, NASA says that the 887 NEOs it knows about are not a serious danger to our planet.

After he decides to go to school, Auggie has to face his first day. Like any child starting at a new school, he feels very worried. But because of how he looks, the day is very hard. Nobody wants to sit next to him, and he sees other kids staring at him or talking about him behind their hands. Luckily, he makes friends with Jack, a boy in his class, and Summer, a girl he talks with at lunch. But it is not only the first day that is hard. Auggie soon learns that his classmates do not want to touch him because they are afraid of catching 'the plague' (a disease). As the school year goes on, Auggie has many ups and downs, until an unexpected and very upsetting event at a school camp changes everything.

The two men looked towards the northern end of the property. It stretched as far as the eye could see. Even the fences were barely visible from where they stood. A teenager might be bored and rebellious, but it was impossible to escape on foot. Sam looked at the largest horse, which was stamping its heavy hooves on the ground. Could the boy ride? he wondered. A good rider could get into a lot of trouble out here, miles away from anyone. But maybe there was even more trouble for someone who knew nothing about horses and wanted to get away from his father.

Over 4,000 climbers, aged from thirteen to eighty have been to the top of Everest. Though climbing high mountains in freezing conditions and violent storms is still extremely dangerous, the world's best climbers now look for new challenges. Gerlinde Kaltenbrunner from Austria fell in love with mountain climbing as a teenager. When she left school, she worked as a nurse, but kept climbing in her free time.

After climbing Mount Everest, Gerlinde decided to climb all fourteen of the world's 8,000-meter peaks. To make the challenge even harder, Gerlinde climbs without oxygen tanks. This is risky because low oxygen levels on high mountain peaks can harm brain and body functions. Gerlinde uses her fame as a climber to support a charity for poor children and orphans in Nepal.

If we look around us at the things we have bought at some point in our lives, we would no doubt notice that not everything we own is being put to good use: the thick woollen coat which we thought looked fashionable despite the fact that we live in a tropical country, the smartphone that got put away when we bought ourselves the newest model, the car that only gets used at the weekends, or even the guest room in our house that somehow got turned into a storage room.

Throughout history and across cultures, dreams have been associated with prediction. People thought dreams were messages from spirits, sent to give us knowledge or insight. Even today, many people can recall a time they dreamed about an event, place or person and then, later, the dream came true in real life.

Some of the world's largest and most expensive transport projects have involved building bridges. Bridges are key connections that carry cars, trucks, and trains over water, deep valleys, or other roads. Because of this, they are one of the most important parts of civil engineering and are carefully checked, especially if they collapse.

After weeks of frustration, Gabriela emailed her manager from Sweden about the issues she was facing with her team. Her manager simply asked her if she felt her team was still performing, and what she thought would help her better work together with her team members. Gabriela thought her manager vague and didn't feel as if he was managing the situation properly.

Dogs that live in packs have learnt that humans are more likely to give food to smaller, cuter dogs. So, these dogs are sent to beg for food for the whole pack. Some dogs have even learnt to use the city's metro system to get from one part of their area to another! Scientists are not sure how the dogs know when to get off the train. One idea is that they use their excellent sense of smell and have learnt to recognise the smells of their favourite destinations. Another possibility is that they have learnt to recognise the names of stations they hear in announcements. Either way, metro passengers have now got so used to the sight of dogs on the trains that they travel largely unnoticed by locals.

Ed Stafford from the United Kingdom is the first person to walk the length of the Amazon River. He started by a small stream in the Andes mountains of Peru and arrived at the river's mouth in Brazil, two years and four months later, having walked 6,000 kilometres. The Amazon rainforest is home to poisonous snakes, crocodiles and jaguars, so Ed was always in danger. Luckily, he survived with nothing worse than a few thousand mosquito and ant bites.

In the United Kingdom, the average person spends more than £1,000 a year on new clothes, about four percent of their income. This may not sound like much, but it hides two more worrying trends for society and the environment. First, a big part of this spending is put on credit cards. People in Britain now owe credit card companies about £670 for each adult. This is 66 percent of the average clothing budget. Also, people are not only spending money they do not have; they are also using it to buy things they do not need. The UK throws away 300,000 tons of clothing every year, and most of it ends up in landfill sites.

Ed's walk would have been impossible without technology. He used a radio to ask the people of the rainforest for food and permission to cross their land. Many of them came to meet him and helped guide him through the most difficult land. As he walked, Ed wrote a blog, recording his day-to-day experiences. He used the news interest in his trip to speak out about the destruction of the rainforest and raise money for environmental and children's charities in Brazil and Peru.

Businesses have caught on to how much money can be made from the sharing economy and are seeking to gain from making use of those underutilised resources. A business model that has quickly become very common involves companies. These companies provide an online platform that connects customers with people who can give a certain product or service. Companies like Airbnb act as a link for people. They help people earn money from their empty rooms and houses. These can be rented out as places to stay that bring in money. Another example is Uber, which encourages people to use their own personal cars as taxis to make some extra cash in their free time.

One of the main jobs of modern zoos is to support international breeding programs, especially for endangered species. In the wild, some of the rarest animals have trouble finding a mate and having young. They also face danger from poachers (illegal hunters), loss of habitat, and predators. A good zoo gives these animals a safe place to live and have young. When wild populations get smaller, the risk grows that animals become too closely related. Breeding programs are a safety plan: animals bred in zoos can be released back into the wild to keep a healthy mix of genes.

Both of these kinds of accidents are extremely rare, but boats and trains can cause a bridge to fall for different reasons. With trains, it's the velocity of the impact that can bring a bridge down. With boats, it's the very large weight they have that can bring about the fall, even if they are going very slowly when it occurs. The best way to avoid bridge failures is to plan for them. Modern technologies that can find structural weakness, safer workplaces and better designs can all help to reduce these terrible accidents.

At first, Pi is terrified of the animals and jumps into the ocean. Then he remembers that there are hungry dangerous fish in the water around him and realises his only option is to climb back into the small rescue boat. One by one, the animals in the small rescue boat kill and eat each other, till only Pi and the tiger are left. Fortunately for Pi, the tiger, who he names Richard Parker, is sick from the boat moving and has no immediate interest in eating him.

When Pi is 16, a new government is elected, which his parents do not support. Worried about the future, Pi's parents decide to close their zoo and move to Canada. They sell some animals to zoos in North America. The family then travels to Canada by ship with the remaining animals. On the way, a terrible storm hits, and the ship sinks. Tragically, Pi's family and all the sailors on the ship drown. However, Pi finds himself in a life raft with a hyena, a zebra, an orangutan, and a large tiger.

The Hunger Games is a very successful book for teenagers and young adults by the American author Suzanne Collins. Since it was published in 2008 it has been translated into 26 different languages and has sold millions of copies around the world. It is also the first book for young readers to sell more than a million electronic copies. The Hunger Games is now a major Hollywood film and is just as successful. It made 152.5 million dollars in its opening weekend in North America alone!

Maybe dreams happen because our mind tries to organize the thoughts we have during the day. But in dreams, these thoughts appear with special meanings and symbols. When we are awake, our thoughts usually come as words in our head, like conversations we have with ourselves. But when we sleep, the part of our brain that controls language becomes less active. At the same time, the part that controls our emotions becomes more active.

Having good relationships is a big part of being happy. In one study, most happy people were seen to have strong ties to friends and family. They made sure they spent time with them regularly. You also need at least one person who you discuss personal feelings with – called 'self-disclosure'. Just one person for a heart-to-heart is enough, together with a network of other relationships. It's not enough to have lots of friends just to do things with or chat to about music or football. That deeper connection is all-important. Some people need to learn how to listen well to others in order to develop stronger relationships.

Psychologist Carol Dweck believes in the 'Growth Mindset.' She talked about how our brains can change and how we can develop skills and talents that we were not good at in the beginning. Many of us like to praise the final result and natural talents. For example, we say 'You really have an eye for details' or 'You have a real talent for organizing events.' However, research shows something different. When we focus on the process - how things are done - we can help people develop new skills better. This means we should praise effort, trying new things, and problem-solving strategies. This way, people can keep improving their talents and learning new skills.

The rover regularly checks the air around it. In 2014, it found methane in the air. Methane is a basic organic molecule and a key part of natural gas. Methane only lasts for a few hundred years. This means something on Mars must be making new methane. NASA says Mars sends out thousands of tons of methane at a time. The amount of methane goes up and down with the seasons each year. It is almost like the planet is breathing.

Early in her career, Carol Dweck, a psychologist from Stanford University, gave some problems to a group of ten-year-olds. The problems were a bit too difficult for them. One group reacted positively. They said they loved challenges and understood that they could develop their abilities. She says these children had a 'Growth Mindset'. They focused on what they could achieve in the future. But another group of children felt that their intelligence was being judged and that they had failed. They had a 'Fixed Mindset' and couldn't imagine getting better. Some of these children said they might cheat in the future. Others looked for someone who had done worse than them to feel better about themselves.

Horror films love empty places. This could be an empty hospital, a scary empty house or a ghost town. There's something about lonely, empty places. What was it like when people lived there? Why did they leave? Maybe it's also that they are so quiet, which can be very scary too. Of course, empty places are also handy for horror film directors in that it's easier to believe that you will have no phone coverage there either.

In horror movies, the basement is always a very scary place, no matter what kind of house it is. Usually, something hides there, or an evil psychopath has hidden their tools there.
