Basements are always dark and often damp. You can only reach them down a narrow staircase. And basements are always creepy, even if nothing is down there.

Gary Collins, an off-duty policeman, was watching the London riots on TV. He immediately recognised several people and finished his holiday early to help identify them. He spent six months watching CCTV videos. He managed to identify 190 people, many just from their eyes. His help was very important for the investigation. Even with 200,000 hours of video, facial recognition software only identified one person.

I personally find it fascinating to think about how we will speed up our evolution as humans by improving our bodies. Imagine if you could put a computer inside our brain! Soon we will be able to do exactly that and make our math skills, our sight and hearing, and our memory better. This idea will become more and more normal.

It was a fascinating talk and the speaker was really right about some points. Take parental influence, for example. How can we expect teenagers not to text while doing homework when they see their parents posting on social media while cooking dinner or waiting at a red traffic light? She also made a good point about people who want to be in two or more places at the same time. So they switch back and forth between their real conversations and online conversations. I see this all the time with my teenage daughter and her friends. They make plans to meet and then sit together silently while each one has a different conversation online.

As for news stories that make us think the world is an increasingly violent place, there is reason for some hope too. Between the end of World War II and 1990, there were 30 wars that killed more than 100,000 people. Today there are still civil wars, but countries are mostly living together more calmly than in the past. However, terrorism has shot up in the last few years and, since World War II, wars have killed many more civilians than soldiers. Even for civilians, the numbers are not all bad. Although deaths are nine times more likely to be a result of violent crime than political conflict, the global murder rate fell slightly, from 8 per 100,000 people in 2000 to about 5.3 in 2015.

Wasfia has dedicated her life to supporting human rights and has seen numerous international aid programs in her home country to educate and train women and girls. But once too often they have been left with nothing when such programs have stopped running. Wasfia saw that Bangladesh needed to stand up for itself. So she brought together two of her passions, mountaineering and human rights, in order to try and change attitudes towards women in her country. She at first took up climbing while working on aid efforts in Tibet and Nepal. In a coastal, primarily flat country like Bangladesh, most people have never set eyes on a mountain. Her effort seems to be doing the trick as other men and women in her country are sitting up and taking notice along with the rest of the world.

Most people believe that developing countries are in a terrible situation: They suffer from extreme poverty, are ruled by dictators, and have little hope for real change. But surprisingly, this is far from the truth. The reality is, however, that a big change is happening. In the last 20 years, more than 700 million people have increased their income and left poverty behind. Also, six million fewer children die from diseases each year, millions more girls go to school, and millions of people have access to clean water.

Many managers try to make feedback more positive by putting negative comments between two positive ones. However, when feedback becomes this kind of routine, employees may start to see positive feedback as just a way to make the negative parts seem less bad. This makes the positive feedback less valuable. Instead, positive feedback should not just be used to soften negative comments. It should be given in a way that strengthens and encourages good performance.

I am a member of the Campaign to Stop Killer Robots. Do not think about scary robots from movies like Terminator. Instead, think about what is happening now: military machines like drones, gun turrets, and sentry robots already kill with very little human control. The next step will be robots called 'murderbots'. These 'murderbots' will follow orders, but they will choose who to kill by themselves. I believe this is completely wrong and dangerous for all people. We must be very careful about what we ask machines to do.

In general, more people are studying English than the other languages combined and English is spoken in the highest number of countries. However, Chinese has by far the greatest number of native speakers. There seems to be little correlation between how many native speakers there are of a language and the number of learners, but there is a stronger link between the number of learners and how many countries have speakers.

Your manager stops you and says she needs to talk to you about your performance on the recent project. You spend the whole weekend worrying, wondering if you did something wrong. On Monday morning, you enter her office. She starts by praising your good work on the project, and you wonder if this is the usual compliment that begins the typical 'feedback sandwich.' You know how the feedback sandwich works: first, say something nice, then say what you really want to say, and finally say something nice again.

'Born in the USA' is a fast, energetic rock album. The lyrics also show deep emotion. Behind the catchy rock melodies, there are stories about the darker side of the American dream. Many songs talk about hardworking, ordinary people who feel bitter and angry when they do not find wealth or fame. For example, 'Glory Days' is about people in a small town who look back on their youth, when they felt the world was at their feet. 'Downbound Train' tells the story of a young man whose life is ruined after he loses his job. It is easy to imagine that the artist is writing about real people he knows. He might even be describing the life he would have had if he had not become a star. The album shows that the Boss has a unique and outstanding talent.

Lewis wants the number of marine protected areas in the world to rise from 3% to 10% to undo damage caused by people, such as overfishing, pollution, and plastic waste. On his expeditions, he saw this damage up close. He swam over coral reefs that had turned white because the water is getting warmer. In the shallow waters of the Red Sea, he saw places like underwater deserts: no life, covered with plastic. He believes that nature can heal if we give it space, but time is running out. If we do not start to care for our seas, we may soon face a problem we cannot solve.

Best-selling author Terrie Sharp can tell a good story or two. She has already won the Olive Crime Writer Award twice. She was born in a housing estate with the highest crime rate in Glasgow. There she learned to keep quiet, stay out of trouble, and even open car doors with a knife. Luckily, she used this knowledge only to write her novels. Today she is not so quiet: she appears on popular morning TV shows like Police Today and speaks at writing conferences around the United Kingdom.

Some people worry that things are getting worse every day. They might think progress is not possible. But in his book, Enlightenment Now, Steven Pinker looks at how humans have made progress. He finds good news. He says that we now live longer, healthier, freer, and happier lives. Pinker says the real problem is that people are attacking important ideas like reason and science. These ideas come from the Enlightenment. When people who speak in public try to make others feel divided, hopeless, or not trusting, then important systems can be badly hurt. These important systems include democracy and countries working together.

In older horror films, when main characters were in great need, it was difficult or impossible for them to call for help or call the police. Mobile phones have made that situation a bit harder to believe now. What's the solution to maintain tension? No phone coverage! If you're a hero in a horror film, it's almost certain this will happen at a key moment, just when you absolutely need to call for help. You will not have any coverage at all. Or your phone battery will die just as you are making the call. Or both.

In the 1950s, commercial banana growers in Central America were about to lose their most profitable product: the Gros Michel banana, known as 'Big Mike.' Now the same thing is happening again to the type that came after it—the Cavendish. The Gros Michel was the main banana on Central American plantations because its fruit was easy to transport, had thick skins, and tasted sweet. United Fruit, the leading grower and exporter in South America at that time, produced bananas very efficiently and on a large scale. Instead of growing plants from seeds, the company made copies of plants by taking shoots from the stems and grew them in fields planted very close together.

Simplified: Most types of spiders have poison. They use it to make the animals they hunt weak or to kill them, not to attack people. In fact, only 25 types of spiders that we know about make poison that can hurt people, and spider bites can be painful, but they almost never kill people. In Australia, the famous funnel-web spider from Sydney has caused no deaths since a medicine against the poison (antivenom) was made in 1981. However, take care not to stroke or handle spiders that are covered with hair, like the big spiders called tarantulas, in a way they do not like. When they feel in danger, they protect themselves by shooting out a cloud of tiny, itchy hairs. These itchy hairs then stick in the skin or eyes of the attacker.

This horror film cliché was especially popular with horror films of the late 20th century. It starts with a group of teenagers all enjoying themselves, and it ends with everyone dead except one girl. At the beginning the girl is usually innocent, shy and not particularly strong. By the end, she has become the strongest and most capable person in the world. The last girl almost always wins in the end.

To understand how we developed complex language, we need to look at how our brains are different from other animals. This is not just about brain size. It is also important what our brains can do, and when and why they changed. We have very few physical clues for this. Old objects left by our ancestors do not tell us what kind of speech they could make. However, one thing we can see in the remains of early humans is how their mouth, throat, and tongue developed. By about 100,000 years ago, humans could make complex sounds. Before that, scientists can only guess if early humans communicated with more basic sounds.

It is society, not nature, that tells us girls should favour arts and humanities and leave maths and physics to the boys. Coupled with this is the lack of positive female role models young people see doing science-connected jobs. Cartoons and stories often show the crazy scientist, very smart creator, or brave astronaut as a man. Furthermore, there is an unfortunate belief that scientists are not cool, have poor social skills or that their work is lonely and separate from the rest of the world. These are false fixed ideas shown by news and TV, but they may mean girls do not feel close to scientists, and see science as an unattractive career path. If girls saw more positive female role models in science it would give them more confidence and a greater sense of belonging in those subjects.

'The Scallion' is a weekly newspaper that is given out for free in faculty buildings. It reaches about 10,000 students and is completely written and produced by students. A survey shows that both students and staff value it for entertainment, cultural enrichment, and work experience. However, printing costs are high. Some students also find it hard to get a copy because they must visit the university in person. Another environmental problem is that many copies end up as waste on campus.

At Girox Foods, about 12% of our employees leave each year. This might not seem like a lot at first glance. However, the average for our industry is only 7%. The main goal of this report is to understand what makes employees engaged in our company. Then, we will suggest ways to improve their experience at work and help them stay with us longer.

Much of what the speaker said was true. I really believe there is a danger: the more connected we are, the more isolated we feel. I do not think this is a big problem for my generation, which lived for a long time without technology. We know how to be alone, and more importantly, we know it is okay to be alone. But people under 20 are different. They are so busy communicating that they never feel what it is like to be alone, and they may not learn to enjoy their own company. They also learn to talk through messages that you can edit and change. This hurts the skill of real, face-to-face conversation with the person sitting in front of you.

Don't always follow positive feedback with negative feedback. If positive and negative feedback always seem to come together, the positive feedback might lose its value and be ignored. Make sure there are times when positive feedback is given just for being positive, and try not to offer any constructive criticism then.
